Hello JBM,

I'm of course not opposed to quantitative tests. I'm actually a=
 big fan of them if they are informative. Also, if someone does make a quan=
titative claim (e.g. performance is higher with algorithm X than Y), then I=
 insist on a p-value as a reviewer. Statistics and quantification are impor=
tant scientific tools, and in most cases should be present. 

However, my p=
oint is that you don't *always* need a quantitative test. I agree that ther=
e are many papers that describe some very complex system, show some cool re=
sults, and we don't learn anything. But sometimes there are papers that sho=
w something extremely impressive and don't have any informative quantitativ=
e measures, and we learn a lot. It is the job of the reviewer to judge whet=
her there is a contribution: but a reviewer should not start with the assum=
ption that "if there is no quantitative test, it's not science and is not p=
ublishable." My guess is that you agree with that, right?

Here is one stro=
ng argument for not mandating a quantitative test: we have not created AI y=
et, so there are many things that humans can judge better than computers/qu=
antitative tests. Take computer vision, for example. All of us are blown aw=
ay by the images that resulted on Picbreeder, yet no one can put a number o=
n why Picbreeder images are more impressive than the images that came befor=
e with interactive evolution. Picbreeder taught us a lot about why CPPNs ar=
e powerful and interesting, but they did not do so with numbers. My guess i=
s that the Picbreeder papers did jump through some hoops to provide numbers=
 to satisfy reviewers that insist on them (I forget at this point, it's bee=
n a while since I read those papers), but those numbers likely taught us ve=
ry little about the central advance. 

The same is true for many domains: i=
f I come up with a new story-telling algorithm, the judgement of whether it=
 is a huge advance would be you listening to the stories and thinking about=
 whether they feel more natural and impressive than what came before. Of co=
urse, it would be better to have an "impressiveness" number if we could hav=
e a good one, but we can't, so any attempt to do so would be simply to appe=
ase those who insist on quantification. We could also do Mechanical Turk an=
d have human judges score the stories=85.and people do that=85.but that is =
expensive, annoying, and often just confirms what you can judge for yoursel=
f as a reader/reviewer. 

Do you agree?


Best regards,
Jeff Clune
